posts.author: charleswatkins
posts.content:
I'm new to NWN but I know my way around Baldur's Gate and Divinity. A buddy and I want to start a co-op game and seeing all the effort here that's gone into character builds, I'm wondering if there might be a guide for two player co-op.  What are some builds that work well together?

I'm used to playing some kind of Fighter/Thief and my partner is a cowardly Sorcerer. But I gather NWN is going to be a bit more complicated.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
It's a big question, Charles. Oh, and hello and welcome, btw!

It took me a long time to adjust to Neverwinter from Baldur's. It wasn't so much the rule changes as the lack of a party, because Neverwinter is predominantly a solo or minimally co-oped game. Thus, many of the builds you'll find here are completely self-sufficient and require no companions. There are hundreds - if not thousands - of options just for solo play, so the multipliers involved for a co-op guide would be astronomical!

That said, a Fighter/Rogue (not a Thief anymore) type should give a good melee presence - though you'll have to decide whether you want a strength or dexterity based one. And a caster of some kind - Wizard/ Sorcerer/ Bard or a more Divine rooted one - would make a worthy addition.

Give us a few more details of the kind of build(s) you're looking for and we'll be happy to oblige.

Cheers

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Look, I get the "you have to learn to walk before you can run" blather.  I do, I get it.

But regardless of build, equipment, etc, the first time anyone runs into the Dire Spider in that sewer, especially coming from BG style of D&D (although the OP does say they are familiar with Divinity) is going to be screaming as they die multiple times.

It's like an abrupt, rude shock of difficulty.

NWN and 3rd Ed uses Damage Reduction rules.  And they can be a bit complicated as to how to penetrate (re : do damage against) them.

Having a second player (meaning double the resources, etc) makes things much easier - but that spider is probably going to kill you both anyways.  It will most likely take you both time and experience to understand what works (and what doesn't).  3rd edition rules have LOTS of things to learn in them.  Hell, the existence of this place alone is testimony to that!

The first thing to be aware of with the OC is that it was made for characters level 1 ~ 20.  Meaning level 40 builds will not help here.  Also, unless one is going to be scamming the system, there is a finite amount of XP available. Also, there is a limit on what type of items one will find or can purchase, create, etc.

We have a section here with level 20 builds - preepic-level-20-builds-f6/

Using any one of these will lead to better results.

Normally, I would suggest a Tank character (meaning one that can stand and fight, and reasonable expect to survive some blows as well as dish some damage out) and a nuker (which means someone who can really deal the AoE (Area of Effect) damage.  Having some healing will be helpful, but not absolutely necessary as healing is always available via the Recall Stone and Temple.

The NWN OC will first take you through the Prelude (I seriously cannot believe that Mick died there, but perhaps he got critted). It is basically a "how to do the basics" of NWN.  Movement, access inventory, the character sheet, basic combat, ranged combat, etc.  And it does a pretty good job of this imo.

But once leaving the Prelude, things get complicated, quickly.  You will be offered a choice of paths you can take.  What is important to note about the different paths, is that they favor different classes (meaning they offer different strengths/weaknesses in the form of challenge).  Where one build will thrive, another may struggle a bit due to how the areas are tailored. 

Later, the challenge will pick up as the more complicated abilities, feats, and spells, etc become available (both for and against you) - it is seriously possible to totally gimp your build to the point of absolute uselessness.

Using builds from the link I have provided will go a long way towards avoiding that fate.

Other than that, after getting through the learning curve, it is basically as I said - anyone and their grandmother can beat the OC with a sharp stick.  It is made to be like this.

One thing that one might want to know is that Bards have it easiest in the OC due to Bioware bias.  I guess they considered Bards weak, or something.  Anyways, having a Bard along is going to really boost the viability of your game.  Just get to know the intricacies of Bard Song and Curse Song and you will be good to go.

I am not sure how the OC handles co-op play in regards to XP.  I do know that using Henchmen and Familiars/Summons reduces XP, so there is that.  Not that it is going to be a major factor in the game - as I have previously mentioned, the OC is not designed to be difficult (with some noteable exceptions).  Those exceptions are well documented these days (not like it was when I first played the game back when it first came out) and strategies and tactics with how to deal with them are readily online.

What I will suggest is this : if one gets "stuck" (like with the Dire Spider) then one should go another way, earn XP, level up, then come back later.  This will often unlock abilities, feats, items, etc that will make a previous encounter that was difficult a breeze.

I envy you that this is all new - I wonder how far it will take you and your co-op buddy.  If you both like what you experience, you might want to skip Modules altogether and go for the Online (Persistent World) experience.  With hordes of different custom created worlds out there, the amount of fun one gets for the basic cost of the game is basically unlimited.  This also goes for the custom created Modules, of course, but Persistent Worlds where there are lots of players really changes how the game feels.

It completes it imo.

I play on the World of Greyhawk.  It is a Persistent World that is based on the original World of Greyhawk intellectual property of Gary E. Gygax, the creator of D&D (some say co-creator).  It is a pretty hardcore world, but it contains most of the D&D modules that a lot of us grew up playing in Pen and Paper (PnP) and is quite nostalgic in that sense (though it is based in the more recent timelines of Greyhawk, so there is that).  It is probably not the first stop for a beginner, as it is a rather difficult environment, harsh and challenging (even for those of us who consider themselves experienced). 

Whatever you do choose to do, I hope it leads to hours and hours of fun and excitement, as it has for me all these many, many years.

NWN is an exception, a jewel, a bright star, that stands out from all others as a game.  There will most likely never again be a game quite like it in our lifetimes.  It's worth a play, and even more worth a stay.

One thing does have to be said here - if you are planning to do the OC, then go into SoU and HotU, you should be aware that the OC does NOT go into SoU!  Basically, SoU is another version of the OC, in that it is for beginning characters.  It was made due to a screaming majority asking for better RP elements, storyline, etc.

HotU can be played from both the OC and from SoU, dependingly.  It is basically your "Epic Adventure" in a nutshell - and it does accomplish this.

Whatever you do or decide, I wish you fun!  I am very confident that NWN can provide you with exactly that, regardless of the form that one is used to.  There is a flavor for everyone.
